rename.to: [BUG] FeatureSelection on pd-multiindex:  Error in check_is_mtype, more than one mtype identified: ['pd-multiindex', 'pd_DataFrame_Table']

body: can you kindly paste the code that produces the error? Minimal code would be great, without loading any data etc.

issue.title: [BUG] transformers: output type check fix for ambiguous return types

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Fixes #2841.

The output type checks in transformers could run into problems in the specific case where the inner `_transform` produced a `pd.DataFrame` that was compliant both with a `Panel` and a `Table` specification.

In cases where this happened, the transformer would error out.

This is easily fixed, since we *know*  when to expect a `Panel` or a `Table`, based on the output scitype. The bug has been fixed by using that tag to restrict the expected outputs, which prevents multiple type identifications.

body:
> Also, I was wondering if there was a way to retrieve the numeric value of feature importance, in order to generate a plot representing feature importance for the dataset?

@CelieDs, the `regressor_` argument contains the sklearn regressor, which you can inspect for feature importances if the estimator offers that functionality.

@CelieDs, speculative fix here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2843
but would be great if you have self-contained code that we can use for testing.

Thank you for your prompt reply and the fix. 
I added all the code that generates the error in the 'To Reproduce' section of the bug report. The other parts of the code correspond to the data importation and some checks on the types, missing values etc...

Thanks for reporting.

The general condition for the bug is the following combination condition:

(a) a transformer is used that handles `y` in a non-trivial way
(b) the transformer is of a kind where `y` is a time series (not a table)
(c) both `X` and `y` are in `Panel` or `Hierarchical` format (scitype)
(d) `y` is passed in a `pandas.DataFrame` based data type format (mtype)

In that case, the code could identify `y` to be a table as well as one of the hierarchical formats, since the "candidate set" of types included both `Table` and `Panel` or `Hierarchical` (which both include `pandas.DataFrame` based type representations that have joint inhabitants).

The solution restricts the candidate set to one of the two, i.e., either `Table`, or `Panel`/`Hierarchical`, based on what we know must come out of the transformer

Some self-contained dummy code for testing:

```python
from sktime.datatypes import get_examples
from sktime.transformations.series.feature_selection import FeatureSelection

X = get_examples("pd-multiindex")[0]
y = get_examples("pd-multiindex")[1]

transformer = FeatureSelection(method="feature-importances", n_columns = 20)
transformer.fit_transform(X, y) 
```

issue.title: [BUG] Vectorization in transformers overwrote y with X

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Thie fixes the following unreported bug related to https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2841 and https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711:

when a transformer entered vectorization mode and `y` was passed (and also vectorized), then the transformer would pass the vectorized `X` to the inner methods where a vectorized `y` should have passed, i.e., passing `X` as `X` (correctly), and `y` as `X` as well (incorrectly). This has been fixed.

(was difficult to spot since the condition is a rare combination of (a) a transformer uses `y` at all, and (b) vectorization happens)

Relation to the bugs:
* after the type inference bug in #2841 is fixed, the test example posted by me breaks due to this unreported bug
* in #2711, it seem like `X` in the forecaster is not properly aggregated. There is not a clear causal link, and the vectorization in forecasters seem correct. Still there is something going on that seems similar, so I reference it.

body: @CelieDs you can use `feature_importances_` attribute, see API reference on website

Hello! Sorry for the delay in response.
Thanks a lot for your reactivity! I was wondering how to get the version of sktime with this fixed? Should I download the development version?
Thanks in advance!
You could install the dev version, or wait for the 0.12.1 release which will happen, I think, today or tomorrow.
